Name: The War on the Ground: World War 2 Wargame Rules
Description:
Experience the harsh realities of commanding your own force. When lives are on the line and victory is in the balance, there are no easy decisions.

War on the Ground is a game system for tabletop actions, designed to give a realistic and enjoyable game for 12mm/1:144 scale miniatures. 
The game covers all aspects of WWII combat including infantry, armour, artillery and aerial encounters.

These rules also include a separate fast play reference sheet and five historical scenarios to get you started.

5 historical scenarios in Normandy 1944:

     Barneville (18th June)
     Operation Mitten (27th June)
     Panzer Lehr counter attacks (11th July)
     Running into some trouble (18th July)
     The bridge at Flavigny (9th/10th September)


–description from the publisher

Name: Looting Alien Ruins
Description:
Each player commands a small team trying to loot a long abandoned alien city they must deal with each other and also any traps and creatures that may have been left behind by the previous inhabitants.

Ideal for multi player games with any scale of figures as long as they are individually based.

Turn Sequence:
1- Activate the player's forces
2- Roll for random events
3- Roll for the game clock

–description from the publisher

Name: Monopoly: Discotheken
Description:
This Monopoly edition takes you to all the most beautiful and enjoyable that Belgian nightclubs can offer. 
They are ubiquitous and spread across the entire country.
Already for decades they have been an important part of the outing possibilities.

Via Monopoly Discotheken-Discothèques, you will discover the iconic temples of dance, past and present. 
Just think of the legendary nights at La Bush, H2O or La Fuse.
Confetti cannons, moving dance floors, fantastic light shows,… 
It's all part of it!

–description from the publisher (translated)

Name: Command Decision: Volume 1
Description:
12 Scenarios with maps and a variety of tactical options. Largely taken from actual actions across all periods but easily transferable to any period.

Scenarios:

     Hazara 1888
     Ohio 1758
     Pyrenees 1813
     Villers Bocage
     St Crispins Day
     Spotsylvania
     Crete 1941
     Kadesh
     Tarakan 1942
     Scottish Borders
     India 1857
     Spain 1809


–description from the publisher

Name: Tussie Mussie: Expansion Collection
Description:
A wallet collection of expansions for Tussie Mussie:


    Orange Flowers (more flowers)
    Greenery (negative points)
    Ribbons (shared goals)



Muted colors are all well and good, but if you want to stand out you’ll need to add a little orange to your arrangement. Everyone knows that a well-placed Butterfly Weed can set you apart from the crowd. Of course, sometimes the most important part of being a trendsetter is knowing when to buck the trend. Should orange blooms become popular, you’ll need to know when to quit.

If you’re comfortable with the harmonious blend of pinks and purples in the base game of Tussie Mussie, the Orange Flowers expansion is the perfect way to add a pop of color to an old favorite. Orange flowers push the player interaction with their diverse scoring: depending on which you find first, you may want to gather them all for yourself or spread them around the table. There’s also the Nasturtium, a potentially powerful (though situational) card that lets the player reorder their arrangement before scoring. Don’t let another player find out why its meaning is “victory shall be ours”!


A good flower arrangement is as much about the framing as it is the flowers. Long-stemmed roses are always in vogue, and the gentle addition of a leafy fern can enhance the beauty of the blooms. Be sparing with your greenery, however: this is still a flower arrangement, after all.

The Greenery expansion introduces 5 cards that work in an all-new way. Greenery cards are great for adding a few extra points to your arrangement...as long as you don’t go overboard. One will do just fine; any more than that and you’ll lose points. Every face-down offer could be the Greenery that tips the balance, adding a delightful layer to the already rich decision-making of Tussie Mussie.


What good is the gift of flowers without a bow to tie them all together? If you really want to catch the eye of your beloved, don’t neglect the ribbon. A proper ribbon accentuates the arrangement rather than merely being an add-on. The extra effort is sure to pay off handsomely.

If you thought Greenery added something new, get ready for Ribbons! This expansion adds 8 Ribbon cards featuring extra goals that players can score in addition to their arrangement. These goals are visible throughout the game and each game will have 1, 2, or 3 of these cards based on player count. Ribbons don’t add to or replace cards from the deck, so they can easily be played alongside the other expansions for maximum enjoyment.

Name: Mint Works: Phil / Baseball Stadium promo card
Description:
AI Phil ("The Reigning Champion") on one side / Baseball Stadium location on the reverse

Phil - 5 mint capacity

Baseball Stadium: "Gain a mint for every building in your neighbourhood"

This promo was initially available in Tantrum House Season 7 Kickstarter campaign.

Name: Titans: Fields of Blood
Description:
Fields of Blood expansion brings the game a new type of unit -- Cossacks. They enrich armies and lead to even bigger battles on the map. In addition to 15 miniatures, the box contains 8 special Cossack dice and a deck of Support Cards with new actions that provide even more tactical decisions and replayability to the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Titans: 5th Player
Description:
5th Player expansion brings to the game a new Nation -- Holy Roman Empire with its capital in Wien. New Nation means a new ability, new Titan, new Nation Cards, and unique miniatures with all other components necessary to play with this Nation.

—description from publisher

Name: Defence of Rorke's Drift
Description:
A free online print-and-play solitaire 'worker placement' game, simulating the famous British defence of Rorke's Drift on the night of 22 January 1879 at the beginning of the Zulu War.

The player, representing the British, must assign each of 4 dice to one of three actions: fighting off the Zulu attackers, putting out fires, or progressing the passage of time until dawn/relief arrives. Successful, die rolls kill Zulus, protect the defences or mark the passage of time respectively. Any Zulus not killed then inflict casualties on the British.

The game ends in a British victory if the time marker reaches the 10th box on its track, and a British defeat (massacre) if the Zulus inflict 10 casualties.

The game takes 5 mins to play and comes with a 2-player option and several optional rules.

—description from the designer

Name: Español
Description:
"Learn Spanish as you play Berlitz español (sic), the continental word playing card game. The pleasant way to practice Spanish. Exciting, challenging, educational."

"Español is a game designed to give you a fundamental basis for learning the Spanish language. In addition to being educational, it is absorbing and entertaining for both teenagers and adults."

"The object of the game is to form sentences from the words printed on the cards. Points are scored for each card used. Sentences may be constructed with two or more cards."

The player with the highest score at the end of the game is the winner.

Name: DragonCraft
Description:
DragonCraft is a card game about the players playing Hero cards to acquire and hatch valuable Dragon Eggs. The first player to have three victory points provided by hatched dragons wins.

The heroes are usually spending their time in the inn, waiting for adventure. They wait until all four are present in the party - fighter, thief, mage and priest. These days there is a high demand for captured dragons so then they go to the dungeon and return with a captured dragon egg (well they do their best to choose an egg with a dragon inside but sometimes they pick the wrong one containing something worthless like a giant snake or an ostrych). This is the most noble and heroic way to acquire a dragon egg. Real heroes do it this way.

There are some players with less honor who take an easier approach. An approach that includes stealth and shady figures in cloaks. Those players may simply steal eggs from other players. (Actually this happens pretty often) You may say that this is not that heroic and noble but the result is the same and the dragon egg is as good as one that the heroes could get from a long and exhausting adventure.

The acquired egg still needs to hatch. If you have the right cards - two mages - you can hatch the egg. This is a very delicate process where the mages have to use their magic very carefully so that the creature inside the egg is not hurt. (but usually they just blast it with fireballs) Hatched dragons give victory points and the player who first has three wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Mitozo
Description:
Mitozo is an turn-based abstract strategy game with an oriental flavour, designed by Pablo Soto Cid.

It was designed as a pen and paper game for two players, but can be played with a regular square board and "white/black" pieces.

Players take turns to fill every position on the game grid, with only one rule: if the piece to be placed is going to contact the opponent, it also must contact a previous piece from the player.

The goal of the game is to make impossible for the rival to place any more pieces before the board is completely filled.

—description from the designer

Name: Flip Tennis
Description:
A game for 2 or 4 players where the game is played on a rectangular tennis court board. Players flip a disc in tiddly wink style over a net placed in the center of the board . If the disc falls into a specific circled area the player gains points. First player to reach 100 points is the winner.

Produced in Australia by the National Game Company and recorded in the Australian National Archives as being registered in 1903.

—user summary

Name: Coast to Coast: Travelers
Description:
After planning a memorable vacation for your first client, word of your travel agency has spread far and wide. As a result, many new Travelers are lining up outside your door, each one looking for the trip of a lifetime!

This expansion offers variable scoring cards to replace the fixed bonuses attached to each type of location in the base game. With over 500 different combinations, no two games of Coast to Coast will ever be the same!

—description from the designer

Name: De Re BelloLudi: Strategy Game – Ancient and Medieval Warfare
Description:
This ruleset simulates battles in the period of 2000 BCE to roughly 1500 CE, the age which includes Empires as Alexander the Great’s Macedonians, Rome, Carthage, Genghis Khan and Charlemagne.

The game is designed as a multiplayer game but will work just as fine with only two players or even solo. It is written for people with no prior wargame experience, but has enough depth to entertain the experienced wargamers as well. The army structure that is presented, can be easily adapted to the number of miniatures that you have available. Albeit that a large army look suitably impressive. Hopefully, playing the game will encourage you to create your own armies. Similarly, the distances are given in inches for use with 28mm scale soldiers. Feel free to adapt to centimeters should you do not have the space or use a smaller scale of miniatures.

In an ideal battlefield situation the enemy was pinned in place by the threat of cavalry or disorganised by the missiles of infantry. Once this was accomplished, other units could deliver the coup de grace. Tactics were therefore based on teamwork between units, or even armies. Every unit would have its own specific task and if they executed their tasks in unison, success was often achieved. The aim in this game, is not to annihilate the enemy’s units to the last man, but to inflict enough damage, indicated by chips, that morale is reduced and the unit will become shaken or will run away in panic and removed from the tabletop. By a clever combination of movement, shooting and dashing cavalry charges, this can be achieved. The tactics are based on teamwork. Not only within a group, but also between groups and as such, the whole army.

Your role will be that of a commander in an ancient or medieval army. Should more than two players per side be available, one of you will play the part of Commander-in Chief or general. Should any disagreement arise concerning the rules, we suggest you roll a dice. The one who rolls the highest number has it right, for now.
So onwards, to glory!

Sequence of Play:

     making a plan
     roll for initiative
     Command (movement, including initiative moves)
     shooting
     hand-to-hand


An IGo UGo system

Cards or special dice (The dice have 0, 1, 2, 3 and B on them
0-3 dictates how many moves can be made by units in a Command.) are available separately.
Markers and chips can be downloaded in the download section

—description from the publisher

Name: BelloLudi: World War I – Skirmish Game 1914-1918
Description:
This ruleset simulates battles in the period of 1914 to 1918, the years in which the worlds’ nation fought one of the greatest conflicts in human history, the Great War or First World War. The rules will work for skirmishes in this era, but also in conflicts shortly before and after as the Balkan Wars and the various conflicts of the Interbellum were largely fought with the same material and tactics. The first World war was a period of tremendous changes in equipment and tactics. These rules will give you the options of playing the first skirmishes of 1914, the trench warfare that dominated the middle of the war and the combined arms tactics that were developed at the end of the war.

Cards and special dice are available separately.

—description from the publisher

Name: BelloLudi: World War II – Skirmish Game 1939-1945
Description:
This ruleset simulates battles in the period of 1939 to roughly 1945, the age in which the worlds’ nation fought the greatest conflict in human history, the Second World War. The rules will work for skirmishes in this era, but also in conflicts shortly before and after as the Spanish civil war and the Korean war were largely fought with the same material and tactics.

In an ideal battlefield situation the enemy was pinned in place or disorganised by the concentrated fire of infantry and artillery. Once this was accomplished, other units could deliver the coup de grace. Tactics were therefore based on teamwork between units, on fire and movement. Every unit would have its own specific task and if they executed their tasks in unison, success was often achieved. The aim in this game, is not to annihilate the enemy’s units to the last man, but to inflict enough damage that morale is reduced and the unit will become shaken or will run away in panic and consequently removed from the tabletop. By a clever combination of movement, shooting and dashing cavalry charges, this can be achieved. The tactics are based on teamwork. Not only within a group, but also between groups and as such, the whole army.

Your role will be that of a commander of a small group of soldiers. Should any disagreement arise concerning the rules, we suggest you roll a dice. The one who rolls the highest number has it right, for now.

So onwards, to glory!

—description from the publisher

Name: Rompan El Fuego
Description:
Rompan El Fuego gives you all the Troop, AFV, and Gun Classifications you need to wargame the Spanish Civil War in conjunction with 1 man / vehicle = 1 platoon WW2 rules such as the popular Rapid Fire Fast Play Rules For WWII.

Also included are supplementary rules together with a handful of amendments which will bring some of the unique character of this conflict onto your tabletop.

There are also notes on weapons and tactics to be found within the main body of the text.

Name: フェイバリットマーケット (Favorite Market)
Description:
ãƒ•ã‚§ã‚¤ãƒãƒªãƒƒãƒˆãƒžãƒ¼ã‚±ãƒƒãƒˆ (Favorite Market) is a card game from Japan, with players tweeting out their influence.

During a high school festival, students want their favourite food stalls to succeed. So they use their tweets and followers to promote themselves and their trends, through stealth marketing. Players can like tweets and retweet, and try to make the festival more exciting.

The players have a personal trend and combine this with a stall to create up to 20 different combinations. They each secretly support three of the stalls.

There is a deck of tweets (using the actual twitter accounts from the doujin circle and their friends), and retweet cards. By playing tweets, liking and retweeting, they can promote the stalls they support.

On a player's turn, they get to do any two actions from three (same action if they like):

Choose one of the three posts on the common timeline and 'Like' it to apply the card effect.

Refresh the timeline, which turns on new posts and removes old ones from the timeline.

'Retweet', which brings back to the timeline a post that was liked in the past, although its use is limited.

As they players perform the actions, their stock of customers goes down. The game ends when all the customers are gone.

The player who earns the most points wins the game by comparing the number of customers in their supporting shop, secretly decided at the beginning of the game, and finally adding up the bonuses for meeting special conditions.
user summary

Name: 白雪姫のアップルーレット (Snow White Apple Roulette)
Description:
Protect Snow White from the Queen and the traitorous dwarf.
Introducing a fiery social deduction game where you can enjoy deduction and psychological warfare.

Game feature #1: The definitive version of the social deduction system that does not require a game master.
The Snow White camp, the Queen camp, and the Third camp are decided by the distributed character cards.
Be aware that apple tiles will be passed to each player, and if you have a poisoned apple at the end of the game, you will die.

Game feature #2: "Story cards" greatly influences victory or defeat.
Each character has a favorite food item (apple or mushroom).
Each player can deduce the other players' characters by playing the story cards.
It is OK to tell a lie during open conversations.
Since the play progresses according to the story cards, even quieter people can enjoy and play easily.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Snow White

Name: Pixel Tactics: Millennium Blades Promo Set
Description:
These six cards bring some of the classic characters from Millennium Blades into Pixel Tactics!

Part of the Millennium Blades: Collusion Kickstarter rewards.

Name: Wordish
Description:
WORDISH (ΜΠΙΡΙΜΠΟΛΕΞΟ [Biribolexo] in Greek) is a word formation card game, in which sighted and visually impaired players can play together.

The aim of the game is to create as many words as you can and gain the most points.
First, shuffle the cards well, because they come in alphabetical order.
The dealer hands out 11 cards to each player.
He then prepares a biribaki (stack of 11 cards) for each player, or team of players (if there are 4). The biribaki are put to one side for the time being, and the remaining cards are placed in the middle of the table facing down. They are the ‘closed cards’.
To begin the game, the dealer draws a card from the stack of ‘closed cards’.
The letter of this card will receive double points throughout the game.
Each word can only contain one atout card. 
  A word must contain at least three letters.
  The Atout cards represent any letter of your choosing, but have zero value.
Thereon, the player has a choice:

take one card from the stack of ‘closed cards’, or
     
    Collect all the disposed cards, which face upwards and are visible; the ‘open cards’, but only if s/he can use at least one of these cards, (to either form a word or add letters to already formed words).

The player will form as many words as s/he can, which are deposited on the table.

Then, she/he deposits a card onto the stack of ‘open cards’ (or forms a stack of ‘open cards’ if there are none). This marks the end of his/her turn and the beginning of the next player’s turn.
The letters in the words created are ‘locked’ and cannot be used to form other words. It is however possible to add letters at the beginning or end of a word.

In teams of two, the players must sit opposite each other. One player is in possession of the team’s cards, whereas the formed words are placed in front of him/her.

It is only possible to move onto the second round and receive a biribaki, once the player or team has used all other cards and has completed a word consisting of 7 letters.

At the end of all the rounds, the players sum up the points they earned from the words they created, including any bonuses, and they deduct points lost from the cards they were unable to use, including any penalties.

—description from the designer

Name: Chronicles of Drunagor: Age of Darkness – Spoils of War
Description:
These Stretch Goals from the Chronicles of Drunagor: Age of Darkness Kickstarter bring to you more fun and excitement with new Hero options, featuring new classes that give you another layer of strategy and battle-oriented interactions! Do not cheer so fast though, here you will find incredible new monsters that will bring a whole new level of tactics and unpredictability to your encounters as well. Be ready! -from the back of the game box.

Contains:

35 Miniatures

     12 Heroes
     14 small monsters
     6 chests
     3 pets


92 Cards

     20 class
     12 hero initiative
     8 monster
     48 hero skill
     4 familiar


12 Deluxe Class Boards
5 Hero Boards
12 Deluxe Hero Boards (11 double faced)
5 Deluxe Dungeon Role Boards
3 Game Trayz organizers

Name: TaleMore: Fantasy
Description:
The Eternal Lands are on the verge of destruction. After 1000 years of peace and harmony, the Dark Lord Asgamon has risen from the depths of the world to terrify the land and its people.

Slip into the role of one of the eight intrepid heroes and face the darkness. Gather your servants of light around you and defeat Asgamon and his entourage.

Embark on a journey full of danger. Always face new dangers and grow stronger step by step. This is the only way to gain access to the dark fortress. But are you strong enough to defeat the Lord of Darkness?

Name: The Doomsday Project: Episode 2 – The Battle for the Balkans
Description:
The Doomsday Project is a subseries of the Operational Scale System featuring wars that never happened.  There will be games on the Persian Gulf, the Balkans, the far north, the Far East, the strategic naval war, and of course, a game of total nuclear war.  Episode Two, The Battle for the Balkans game, as you will see in all additional games in The Doomsday Project, will add another facet to the mechanics of the system. Sophisticated political rules will make their appearance. Players will have to contend with heads of state and their positives and negatives in play. Rules to retrofit these rules into the Germany game will be provided as well.

Product information

Complexity: 7 out of 10
Solitaire Suitability: 8 out of 10
Time Scale: 1 day per turn
Unit Scale: Divisional/Brigade/Regiment
Players: 1-2
Scenarios: 5 (+1 massive campaign game with The Battle for Germany)

—description from the designer

Name: Stop Thief
Description:
A Morton Thinking Cap game produced in the 1960s.

In Stop Thief one player is the police and the other players are robbers in a game of cat and mouse. Rolling a die to move or using the bus routes available the robbers roam the city to steal cash from the banks and post offices. The robbers try to avoid being captured by the policemen on the beat or the patrol car.

The police earn bonus cash by catching robbers red-handed after a theft and if a robber is gaoled four times they are eliminated from the game. The robbers stash their loot in hideouts until they can afford the fare to leave the country by train, ship or aeroplane.

The winner is the player with the most money at the end of the game which can be either the police in the city or one of the robbers who has successfully escaped abroad.

—user summary

Name: 2020: Extension Pack +
Description:
A game designed for those that wish to leave 2020 behind! Create your circle of friends to help you survive the financial hardships of 2020. Do whatever it takes to survive this year above the rest but remember: Problematic players lose their jobs, sponsorships, friends and sometimes even money.

Players gain survival points based on the cards that they play, and when a player has acquired fifteen survival points, the end of the game is triggered. At the end of that round, players count their money and the player with the most money wins.

With the 2020: Extension Pack +, players will encounter 52 exclusive social media cards that give players the a chance to look back and laugh at the monstrosity of 2020.

—description from the designer

Name: Yankee ASL Nor'easter Pack II
Description:
3 New ASL Boards and 15 scenarios designed by the Yankee ASL'ers, a group of ASL players in the Boston area.  This scenario pack has no particular theme and stretches from a Polish scenario in September 1939, through the Korean war in 1950, and the French Indochina war in 1954.

This is a follow on to the 20th Anniversary Scenario pack which was produced in 2016 for tournament play, but this time the pack was produced and sold by Le Franc Tireur.

Name: Pumpkin Killer Man
Description:
A card game based on a simple turn by turn system, on your turn turning over cards to find villagers, to gain points, but if you draw Pumpkin Killer Man, you're dead! Try to save the people of Fallville, and get out alive. This game includes many different ways to play and extra rules to add mechanics to the base style of play.

—description from the designer

Name: Forgotten Battles from France to Germany: January to April 1945
Description:
This book contains 23 battle scenarios, covering the period of January to April 1945. It also includes special rules for each scenario.

New weapons, armour and infantry types can be applied to any set of rules. Including War on the Ground.

If you are under the impression that the last few months of the Second World War in Western Europe was a ‘walk in the park’, this book will prove otherwise!

Some of the hardest fighting took place from January to April 1945 and here you will find historical battles, which most will not have come across before. 
The scenarios are testing and will be a challenge for all wargamers.

–description from the publisher

Name: 英雄对决 (Hero Battle)
Description:
GAME SYSTEM

    
    
         This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.

    


A trading card game published by Chinese collectible card publisher Kayou.
In this game, players can use heros from Ultraman Universe or Marvel Universe to fight with the opponent.
At the start of the game, each player draw 9 cards and set 5 of them on the field, other 4 cards are their hand. In each turn, player should choose a card on the field to fight the opponent, the player who has 5 heroes defeated will lose the game.

So far, the series has published two Marvel basic packs and two Ultraman basic packs, as well as three Marvel booster packs and two Ultraman booster packs.

Name: Warhammer Age of Sigmar (Second Edition): Broken Realms – Be'lakor
Description:
While the Mortal Realms rage under the fires of countless wars, one scorned figure looks to take advantage and further his unknowable agenda. Be'lakor, the Dark Master, whose schemes have had their twisted tendrils in many momentous events, begins to enact the final stages of his grand ambition. With the beleaguered Stormcast who followed Morathi into the Eightpoints making their retreat back across the Bloodwind Spoil, and the Seraphon beginning their own assault upon Archaon's realm, what could the first and greatest of the Daemon Princes have in store?

The third instalment in the Broken Realms series sees the hidden machinations of Be'lakor come to the fore as the Dark Master begins to take a more direct role in the Mortal Realms' events. The dire consequences will ripple across multiple factions, including an unforeseen alliance between Chaos and Death, the march of the Seraphon's Celestial Stampede, and the introduction of siege warfare to Warhammer Age of Sigmar.

Inside this 112-page hardback book, you'll find:


     The chilling tale of Be'lakor's grand plan to usurp the Everchosen and take his place as the foremost champion of Chaos



     Rules for the Legion of the First Prince, including an expanded warscroll for Be'lakor himself and updated battle traits, spells and artefacts for his Slaves to Darkness warband



     Coalition of Death rules allowing you to play team-based games including 3 or more players, who may need to team up temporarily to take out a threatening foe while keeping an eye out for their so-called 'allies'



     Six battleplans to help you recreate pivotal moments from the story, as well as Realms of Battle rules to represent the unique locations they were fought in



     Rules to tie the battleplans into a narrative campaign depicting Be'lakor's assault upon the Mortal Realms



     A bounty of warscrolls, warscroll battalions and unit updates for Kharadron Overlords, Fyreslayers, Stormcast Eternals, Disciples of Tzeentch, Nighthaunt, and Seraphon


—description from the publisher

Name: Shroom Shroom!
Description:
Buy, sell, and trade all kinds of crazy mushrooms on your way to victory in this exciting, strategic, and family-friendly card game.

—user summary

Shroom Shroom is a super fun and strategic card game about collecting and trading all kinds of crazy mushrooms. Players take turns selling, buying, and trading mushrooms to add to their collections. Try and collect different combinations and families of mushrooms to earn points.

Choose your cards wisely because you can only have up to ten shrooms in your collection at a time. Some cards have special powers that allow you to develop fun or cruel strategies against each other. The thing that makes Shroom Shroom even more awesome is trading. You can trade anything with anyone at any time during the game. While you're waiting for your turn, make some trades with other players to help build up your collection.

When the cards run out, everyone adds up their points and the person with the best shroom collection wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Escaping The Orcs: A Solo Game
Description:
In Escaping The Orcs, you control a group of human slaves trying to escape from their Orcish oppressors.
The game is played over four scenarios as you escape and then search for a safe home while being pursued by angry Orcs.

Ideal for 28mm figures but any scale will do as long as they are individually based.

—description from the publisher

Name: Sci-Fi Return: A Solo Game
Description:
In Sci-Fi Return, you must enter a damaged space station and recover some information.
The station is in danger of falling apart and various dangerous creatures have escaped and are roaming the facility.

This is a sequel to Sci-Fi Escape but is a stand alone game you don't need anything else to play it.

Ideal for 28mm figures but you can use whatever comes to hand.

—description from the publisher

Name: Goblin Trek 2: A Solo Game
Description:
In Goblin Trek 2 you must bring your party of Goblins to safety while being pursued by Orcs through a hostile desert.

A solo game much like the original Goblin Trek but in this game the desert itself is hostile and the terrain areas while possibly home to hostile creatures are also the only shelter from the heat of the desert.

Easy to learn with enough variables to make each game a different experience.

—description from the publisher

Name: Elfs vs Dwarfs: A Solo Game
Description:
Elfs vs Dwarfs is a solo game in which you can play either the Dwarves or the Elves trying to hold out until relieved.

A simple and easy to play game with lots of random options to make each game different.

—description from the publisher

Name: Czech Legion: A Solo Game
Description:
The Czech Legion famously travelled all the way across Russia during the Russian Civil War
This game represent a small skirmish along the way.

A solo game where you command a small group of soldiers returning from a foraging mission with valuable supplies and being attacked by a force of bandits.

This will work in any scale as long as the figures are individually based.

—description from the publisher

Name: Bagration 1944: A Solo Game
Description:
Bagration 1944 is a solo game where you command a Russian infantry platoon trying to clear out some German forces left behind after your forces rapid advance.

Simple to play.
Will work in any scale as long as the figures are individually based, lots of options to keep the game varied each time it is played.

—description from the publisher

Name: After Hastings: A Solo Game
Description:
After Hastings is a solo game in which you have to get a small party of Anglo-Danes to safety in the aftermath of the Battle of Hastings, while being pursued by the victorious Norman forces.

Simple to learn and play requires individually based figures ideally 28mm but any side will do.

—description from the publisher

Name: Vikings: A Solo Game
Description:
Vikings is a solo game where you command a group of Vikings cut off and trying to make it to safety while being pursued by lots of angry Anglo Saxons.

A simple game to learn and play but should be lots of fun with plenty of variable factors to make each game different.

Requires individually based figures ideally 28mm but any scale will do.

—description from the publisher

Name: Dwarfs Last Stand: A Solo Game
Description:
Dwarfs Last Stand is a solo game you command a small force of Dwarfs attacked by hordes of orcs who can't win. 
It is simply a matter of how long you can hold out for.

Easy to learn rules for a fun evenings gaming.

—description from the publisher

Name: Dwarven Beer: A Solo Game
Description:
Dwarven Beer is a solo game in which you have to transport a wagon full of beer across an area infested with goblins who also want the beer.

You command a small group of Dwarfs plus the beer wagon the goblins are controlled by the rules.

The game has plenty of random factors to keep it different every time you play, easy to learn and fun to play.

—description from the publisher

Name: Market Trend
Description:
Market Trend is a market game from Japan, with players working as jewellers. The price of the different gemstones varies according to demand; when players put out new designs and clusters, prices go up, and fall for the gems out of popularity. Players aim to be the richest jeweller by the end of four rounds.

The game has 120 gem cards for different types, from 10 diamonds to 24 jet. The deck is varied for the number of players.

Once the deck is prepared and shuffled, players are dealt 8 hand cards. (If the deck is exhausted leter, discards are shuffled over).

Players then select one card to keep as stock, placing it face-down in front of them, and pass their hand to their neighbour (alternating each round). Then players can sell gems or sets of gems from their hand and make cash.

The value of what they sell is determined by a scoring plan, and alters each round. At the end of the game, there is a final bonus too.

Players can now move the prices of the gem types up or down, according to what they did and did not sell. After this, players are dealt back to 8 cards (or as best can be done), and the game continues.

At the end of the game, the stock cards the players have been collecting are scored for a final bonus. After this, most cash wins.

The distribution of the gem cards matters, and players try to keep in mind which gems they have seen and which have been sold. Understanding which are going to be rarer by the end of the game is a key strategy.
user summary

Name: Golf Shot Game
Description:
Players take turns rolling three special six-sided dice with three golf balls, "hook", "slice", and "trap". Each player start with three coins. Each dice roll determines what happens to the coins, either pass a coin to the left (hook), pass a coin to the right (slice), put a coin in the center (trap), or keep the coin (golf ball). Game ends when only one player is left with coins, and he/she wins the coins in the center.

—user summary

Name: Tower of Dice
Description:
Tower of Dice is a fast-paced dice rolling dexterity game. The goal is to create a tower of dice faster than your opponent(s) to win the game.

Currently Tower of Dice is a rule set you can download and play yourself at home with 2-6 opponents. You will need a lot of dice...A LOT of dice...depending on the number of players, but two players should get by with 30-40 six-sided dice.

With multiple play modes from basic (stacking dice of like-numbered rolls) to more advanced (using basic math to calculate what your next dice roll should be) the game can satisfy almost any age group for a quick and fun play.

—description from the designer

Name: War Between The Stars
Description:
The exploration of space was carried out primarily by large corporations which soon found out that valuable resources were few and far between and soon they were in conflict over the few good systems. 
After some years things settled down leaving a number of what had become in effect nations looking greedily at each other’s possessions.
The year is 2264 and border skirmishes are common, the discovery of a string of new valuable systems would set off a war that would destroy many of these new nations between the stars.
This war was known as the War of Expansion.

War Between The Stars is a game of starship combat. 
It uses a couple of ships or play larger games with whole fleets, lots of ship designs to use as well as a design system to create your own. 
There are also a few sample scenarios to get you started and as an introduction to the War of Expansion.

The rule are simple and easy to learn but the use of special features allows for the construction of unique fleets that each has its own advantages.

Sequence of Play:

     Starting with whoever has the most ships, the players move alternate ships until all ships have been moved.
     Conduct firing, all of which is considered to be simultaneous. 
     All ships may try to repair damage then 
     start the next move


—description from the rulebook

Name: War Between The Stars: Carriers
Description:
War Between The Stars: Carriers is a supplement for War Between The Stars that introduces the use of Carriers and Fighters into the game.

This is not a stand alone game you will need a copy of War Between The Stars to use it.

Includes some sample ships and a scenario

—description from the publisher

Name: I Need More Trees!
Description:
A set of rules for fighting the French and Indian Wars ideally using 28mm figures but other scales will work as long as the figures are individually based.

Designed to represent the smaller encounters that took place in the forest using maybe 80-120 figures/side though larger multi player games would also work.

Easy to learn and play these rules should keep you on your toes especially when there are Indians hiding in the forest and you don't know where or how many.

Turn Sequence:

     Randomly determine who moves first for the turn
     Alternately activate units until all activation points have been used
     Test morale for all units that have poor morale

Name: Spacefighters: War in the Belt
Description:
As the Earth ran out of resources humanity became more and more dependent on the huge amount of resources available in the asteroid belt. The mining of these was left to a number of corporations that soon started fighting over the most valuable asteroids.
The game represents these encounters between groups of spacefighters played on a hex grid using either counters or model ships normally 2-3 ships/player but larger games are possible and using multiple players will help to model the chaotic nature of these combats.

A set of rules for fighter combat in the asteroid belt.
Needs a hex grid to play and some 10 and 6 sided dice.
You could use counters or models to represent the ships .

The ships are armed with cannons and missiles with limited ammunition so games will come to a natural end rather than continuing until all of one side is destroyed.

Some sample ships are to start with but you can easily design your own.

Turn Sequence:

     Roll to recover control
     Set ship speed unless out of control
     Choose to fly evasive or normal
     If not evasive or out of control can roll to repair damage
     Move out of controlships
     Move evasive ships
     Move all other ships
     Missiles take effect
     Firing with cannons
     Firing with missiles


–description from the rulebook

Name: Subway Network
Description:
Subway Network is a game from Japan. Players are constructing rail networks in Tokyo or Osaka. By building stations, operating typical businesses on the stations, such as convenience stores, and increasing passengers, players score points to win.

The game has a board on which track cards are placed. Each card has three rail lines in different patterns and hence 6 points of entry/exit. Each card also has two stations, of municipal, dept store or skyscraper types.

The 12 business cards score victory points when built. They come in three types, cafes, retail, and two hotels.

The passenger cards score points when certain conditions are met. For example, 2 points for each municipal station on the line.

Players have their own markers; station, train, and action markers. The train markers go onto spaces around the board, marking the start and finish of their rail lines. The action markers go on an action board, which sets player order. In the round, players move their markers to select their actions in the round.

Players can select a business action, draw business cards and select the one they want, passing the remaining cards to other players who selected the same action. Being able to build a mix of businesses can earn bonus points at the end.

Players can then build out their rail line from hand cards dealt at the start and place a station marker. Completing lines allows a player to recover their markers. After this, some additional actions can be triggered, such as building tunnels.

Then conditions are checked for four open passenger cards. If a card is satisfied, players can score points, and the card is discarded. A fourth card is drawn, until no more are available.

The players action markers are moved back to determine the turn order, and rail cards are dealt back to each player and the game continues.

When the map is filled out, the game ends and players calculate their final scores. The most points wins the game for the best subway network builder.
user summary

Name: Munchkin: Santa-Sized Holiday Grab Box
Description:
This is a shipping box for Munchkin - used to ship a bundle of Munchkin items in it.

It comes with special benefits for the owner, the Twelve Bonuses of Christmas. On the box there are various special abilities, such as "Draw one extra treasure when you kill a monster". Each ability has two checkboxes, which have to marked when the bonus is used.

Name: Munchkin: Holiday Grab Box
Description:
This is a shipping box for Munckin - used to ship a bundle of Munchkin items in it.

It comes with special benefits for the owner, the Twelve Bonuses of Christmas. On the box there are various special abilities, such as "Draw one extra treasure when you kill a monster". Each ability has a checkbox, which has to marked when the bonus is used.

Name: Munchkin Special Delivery
Description:
This is a shipping box for Munckin - used to ship a bundle of Munchkin items in it.

It comes with a one-time special benefit for the owner, the Twelve Bonuses of Christmas. It says: "You may show this carton to double the treasure for one combat per game, after you have confirmed your victory but before drawing the Treasure cards."

Name: Chindit Game
Description:
A simple game representing a small group of Chindits trying to reach their base after a mission deep in enemy territory.

The game does not use figures all you need is a piece of paper a pen and a pack of playing cards including the jokers.

Quick and fun to play a game usually lasts less than 10 minutes.

—description from the publisher

Name: Black Seas: Large Xebec
Description:
A Xebec is a two- or three-masted vessel usually found in the Mediterranean that was used mostly for trading. It had a long overhanging bowsprit, an aftset mizzen mast and lateen sails.

Favoured by Barbary Corsairs (Muslim pirates operating off the coast of North Africa) and Algerian Berber corsairs, early xebecs had two masts, whilst later examples had three. The ships were generally smaller than frigates of the period, both in terms of displacement and the number of guns they carried.

The modified ships were oftentimes faster than their victims owing to a narrower floor, and their lateen sails meant that it could sail at great speed close to the wind – lending them a great advantage in pursuit or escape. Xebecs armed in this way would mount between 300 and 400 men and would mount between 16 and 40 guns.

The design was not without its disadvantages; the ships fared poorly in rough weather and high seas, and the sails were vulnerable to enemy dismantling fire. A wise captain would therefore need to pick their battles wisely, and use their ship’s superior manoeuvrability to avoid unwinnable confrontations and instead prey on the weak – striking swiftly to overwhelm their prey and withdraw equally as quickly.

As well as uses in piracy there were some uses of xebecs in national navies as light warships – often as a direct counter to the pirates themselves. The advantages of speed and manoeuvrability did not go unnoticed by coastal traders either – especially those who favoured speed and draft over cargo capacity.

One of the most famous single-ship actions in all of naval history involved a Xebec. On 6 May 1801, the British sloop Speedy defeated the Spanish Xebec-frigate El Gamo. This engagement is the inspiration for many examples of literary naval fiction, perhaps most notably Patrick O’Brian’s Master and Commander.

This pack includes one large Xebec for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for its use with the included ship card.

–description from the publisher

Name: Black Seas: Xebec Squadron
Description:
A Xebec is a two- or three-masted vessel usually found in the Mediterranean that was used mostly for trading. It had a long overhanging bowsprit, an aftset mizzen mast and lateen sails.

Favoured by Barbary Corsairs (Muslim pirates operating off the coast of North Africa) and Algerian Berber corsairs, early xebecs had two masts, whilst later examples had three. The ships were generally smaller than frigates of the period, both in terms of displacement and the number of guns they carried.

The modified ships were oftentimes faster than their victims owing to a narrower floor, and their lateen sails meant that it could sail at great speed close to the wind – lending them a great advantage in pursuit or escape. Xebecs armed in this way would mount between 300 and 400 men and would mount between 16 and 40 guns.

The design was not without its disadvantages; the ships fared poorly in rough weather and high seas, and the sails were vulnerable to enemy dismantling fire. A wise captain would therefore need to pick their battles wisely, and use their ship’s superior manoeuvrability to avoid unwinnable confrontations and instead prey on the weak – striking swiftly to overwhelm their prey and withdraw equally as quickly.

As well as uses in piracy there were some uses of xebecs in national navies as light warships – often as a direct counter to the pirates themselves. The advantages of speed and manoeuvrability did not go unnoticed by coastal traders either – especially those who favoured speed and draft over cargo capacity.

One of the most famous single-ship actions in all of naval history involved a Xebec. On 6 May 1801, the British sloop Speedy defeated the Spanish Xebec-frigate El Gamo. This engagement is the inspiration for many examples of literary naval fiction, perhaps most notably Patrick O’Brian’s Master and Commander.

This pack includes a squadron of three xebecs for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for their use with the included ship cards.

Name: Black Seas: Large Galley
Description:
Though galleys were out of favour by the Age of Sail, they were still used. Galleys are very low, long, and slender ships that use banks of oars as their main mode of propulsion. Identified easily by their long hulls and shallow drafts, they still maintained sails that could be used should the winds prove favourable – though this never superseded manpower as the primary means of manoeuvrability.

In Black Seas, galleys can deploy oars and, if needed, move independently of the wind. While moving under oars, these ships can move as if at Battle Sails, no matter where the wind is coming from. However, as the crew is busy rowing, the ship will shoot with an additional -2 penalty. Galleys may also deploy their sails, following the same rules as all other sailing ships. However, in order to switch from sails to oars, or vice versa, a ship must spend one full Turn without shooting.

Originating in the Mediterranean by the early naval powers – notably the Greeks, Illyrians, Phoenicians, and Romans, the galley remained the predominantly used types of vessels used for both war and piracy in those seas until the end of the 16th century. Though the advent of the lateen sail used in hybrid vessels like xebecs had displaced the use of galleys by the 18th century, the vessels still saw some use. The last recorded battle where galleys took a significant part in the Mediterranean was at Matapan in 1717; however, the vessels enjoyed a brief resurgence in the wars of the 18th century between Russia, Sweden and Denmark.

This pack includes one large galley for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for its use with the included ship card.

–description from the publisher

Name: Black Seas: Galleys
Description:
Though galleys were out of favour by the Age of Sail, they were still used. Galleys are very low, long, and slender ships that use banks of oars as their main mode of propulsion. Identified easily by their long hulls and shallow drafts, they still maintained sails that could be used should the winds prove favourable – though this never superseded manpower as the primary means of manoeuvrability.

In Black Seas, galleys can deploy oars and, if needed, move independently of the wind. While moving under oars, these ships can move as if at Battle Sails, no matter where the wind is coming from. However, as the crew is busy rowing, the ship will shoot with an additional -2 penalty. Galleys may also deploy their sails, following the same rules as all other sailing ships. However, in order to switch from sails to oars, or vice versa, a ship must spend one full Turn without shooting.

Originating in the Mediterranean by the early naval powers – notably the Greeks, Illyrians, Phoenicians, and Romans, the galley remained the predominantly used types of vessels used for both war and piracy in those seas until the end of the 16th century. Though the advent of the lateen sail used in hybrid vessels like xebecs had displaced the use of galleys by the 18th century, the vessels still saw some use. The last recorded battle where galleys took a significant part in the Mediterranean was at Matapan in 1717; however, the vessels enjoyed a brief resurgence in the wars of the 18th century between Russia, Sweden and Denmark.

This pack includes a squadron of three galleys for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for their use with the included ship cards.

–description from the publisher

Name: Dinosaur Hunting!
Description:
In the 1920's a valley was found full of Dinosaurs.
Soon hunters were heading there to try their luck at BIG big game hunting. 

Lead a small group of hunters and see who can get the most trophies or indeed just survive.

Ideal for 28mm figures but will work with any size of figures just use what you have available.

Turn:

     Randomly determine the order in which the players activate each turn. 
     The dinosaurs all activate after the players. 
     On their turn a player activates each figure which can make two actions (move, fire, load or observe) They can do the same action twice if they want but there may be penalties for doing this.


–description from the publisher and the rulebook

Name: The LOOP: The Revenge of Fauxzilla
Description:
The first expansion for The LOOP brings new characters, equipments and game modes.

Your favorite evil genius, Dr. Faux, returns with a terrifying giant monster, Fauxzilla!
Will you let him wreck the Universe?

Play as two new agents, the young Dr. Faux himself and the Peak Twins, to foil his plans in two new game modes.
Dr. Faux is back, and he's unleashed the wrath of Fauxzilla.

This giant monster will soon be rampaging through space-time! The Agency has no choice but to convince the legendary Peak Twins and Faux Klein Schlag to return to action!

Take on Dr. Faux's not-so-domestic giant monster, Fauxzilla, in two new game modes: "Fauxzillapocalypse" puts you on a time-track to defeat the beast. To defeat it, charge and set off powerful energy traps at the right time.

In "The 7 Kaiju Balls", retrieve Fauxzilla's Eggs through time to seal them in their proper era, while dodging the monster's fury.

You can now count on two new characters: Faux Klein Schlag, a young version of Dr. Faux himself, determined to regain the upper hand over his evil future self. And the Peak Twins, the most feared pair of enforcers in the Middle Ages.

New Artifacts and 2 additional Sabotage tiles will take your Loop experience to the next level!

Requires the base game to play.

— Description from the publisher.

Name: Clash of Galliformes
Description:
Explore, build and battle in this strategy and resource management game with ground-living birds set in an alternate timeline where birds work alongside tribal clans. As the clans have developed close to their feathery mounts, their cultures have been formed by their specific clan birds. Some have mastered the way of faster bird breeding while others have gone down a more warlike path. Now is the time to choose your bird and in so doing, your way of life.

Players must expand their territory to find supplies and new technologies for their tribes. The threat from rival clans is also constant, so you have to adapt your strategies and think ahead of your opponents to survive. Will you conquer the other clans by force or will your memory live on through the peaceful measure of completing cave paintings? The choice is yours!

—description from the designer

Name: Tranquility: The Ascent – Friends in High Places Promo
Description: Included for all Kickstarter backers of Tranquility: The Ascent, and with limited availability post-campaign, the Friends in high places adds five unique player powers to the game. Shuffle the powers as part of the setup and deal one randomly to each player. They now have access to one powerful ability that may make the difference between winning and losing.

Name: Gjorn
Description:
Gjorn is a fast, quick-to-learn but very tactical card game for 2-4 players. You will win by making tactical decisions. You need to get ahead of your opponent to dominate the battlefield.

There are five different kinds of cards and each card has its own effect.

There are also 2 kinds of tokens coins and fame. Some of the card effects make you lose coins, but you can never lose fame.

You win by collecting coins and fame. Both are worth 1 point

Card effects:

Axe: Capture 3 coins

Shield: Opponents lose 2 coins

Bow: Capture 1 coin and make your opponent lose 1 coin

Horn: Earn 1 fame

Runestone: Win every tie.

Starting the game:
You shuffle all the cards together and every player gets 7 cards. There are 15 rounds now.

In each round, players place a card face down in front of them and reveal it at the same time.

Players compare all their cards in front of them. And whoever has the most cards of a type, or a tie but most runestones, get the effect of the card.

Who has the most points at the end wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Obsession: Useful Box
Description:
The Obsession: Useful Box contains new content such as promo Gentry cards, Improvement Tiles, Rule cards for new content, Solo Opponent cards for Upstairs, Downstairs, as well as several updated or corrected content from the base game and the Wessex and Upstairs, Downstairs expansions.

The full list of changes is detailed in this thread:
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/2647648/useful-box

Name: Once Upon A Crime
Description: Once Upon a Crime is a party game based on the new "criminal storytelling" mechanic that combines deduction, bluffing and "StoryTelling" in a crime scenario. A player invents a crime by connecting a suspect, a motive, a weapon and a location using the cards on the table and reveals a single clue: who died. The other players must deduce the correct combination by choosing among 4 suspects, 4 motives, 4 weapons and 4 locations. But one or more of the players might be criminals, and they will try to trick them without getting caught.

Name: Farting Frenchies: Tiny Pups Fart, Too!
Description: Stand-alone game and expansion pack featuring a selection of non-Frenchie breeds of dogs. More stink, good smell cards, and actions cards are also included.

Name: Beat Unemployment!
Description:
Players play as a miner, a teacher, a shipworker, an engineer, a shopkeeper, or a company executive. The objective of the game is to not become unemployed. The game board is a circular track with Pay As You Lose and Survival cards placed in two separate decks in the center.

Players take turns rolling dice and moving a Monetarist Fiend playing piece around the board, landing on either a job space or a PAYL space. If it lands on a job space, players pay tax to the Cosmetic Economic Policies Fund according to each occupation provided in a table in the rules booklet. If it lands on a job space that is the player's own, then he/she is paid by the other players. If a player lands on a PAYL space, he/she takes a PAYL card and performs the actions on the card.

—user summary

Name: Farting Frenchies: Labs Fart, Too!
Description: Expansion pack featuring a Labs (Labradors). More stink, good smell cards, and actions cards are also included.

Name: Level 7 [Omega Protocol]: Prototype Energy Weapon Promo
Description:
This is a promotional kit card for Level 7 [Omega Protocol]. It was included with Level 7 [Invasion].

It provides an additional kit card with the following ability:  Roll an additional red die for all your attacks made with your basic ranged weapon.  A commando can have only one copy of this kit card.

This card can be included in the kit card deck during setup.

Name: Escape Room: Das Spiel – Megapack
Description:
Can you ceep a calm mindset?

The game within the trend! Cooperativly experience the atmosphere of an ESCAPE ROOM within your own living room. In this challenging game you cooperativly try to solve riddles and find hidden hints. It´s a race against time; you only have 60 minutes to solve and master all puzzles. Your game-master - THE CHRONO DECODER - is counting down mercilessly, provides background sounds for intensified atmosphere and sometimes even provides precious hints.

At this game you win or lose together. Every player has to try his best to reach the mutual goal - nevertheless you will only succeed whit teamwork. Those who never completed an ESCAPE ROOM will realise, how quick an hour full of adrenaline can pass.
Families: Series: Escape Room – The Game (Identity Games International B.V.)

Name: Cosmic Exodus
Description:
Cosmic Exodus is a strategic area control game for 2-6 players.

Each player takes on the role of a faction leaving earth with the aim of conquering the rest of the system. Along the way players will collect resource cards, and spend them to build space base's, move or warp their command ship to new planets and moons, and complete hidden objective cards.

The player with the most victory points - scored by planetary occupation and hidden objective missions - is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Name: Dungeon & Kingdom
Description:
Dungeon & Kingdom is a 2-4 players tactical card game played in half an hour. 
The game constantly pushes the players’ card arrays to the 7-card limit. Meanwhile, players need to find the perfect point of time to maximize their advantage using the game’s unique Cutting Mechanism to divide their array into Dungeon and Kingdom. 
In the Kingdom the Adventurers fight off Monsters and gain Victory Points. In the Dungeon they perform a wide variety of rules-breaking Hero’s Deed combos!

—description from the designer

Name: Escape from Corregidor
Description:
In May 1942, 18 American crewmen scuttle their US Navy minelayer ship based in the Philippines to prevent it from falling into the hands of the invading Japanese forces. Using a 36-foot US Navy motor launch, the 18 sailors, led by Lieutenant Commander John Morrill (player), begin their 2,000-mile journey through Japanese infested waters in an attempt to reach Darwin, Australia.

Escape from Corregidor is a Print & Play historical solitaire board game of danger and survival. As their leader, you will attempt to lead your 17 men to safety 2,000 miles away in Australia. The dangers you and your men will possibly face include dehydration, starvation, hostile natives, tropical diseases, poisonous snakes, inclement weather, and Japanese enemy aircraft and ships.

Game components include navigation mats, calendar mat, a tables book, and a counter sheet with various counters to location and status of the boat along it's route.

The player moves his boat game counter across the various navigation mats during his journey.

—description from the designer

Name: Letter Rush
Description:
In Letter Rush, 2 players will rush through a pile of letter tokens in a fast-paced color matching word game. Play for points or ability cards that'll give you an edge against your opponent. All cards have colored squares that will match the colors of letter tokens. The players must find letter tokens in the required color patterns, along with making a complete word to claim cards. The player with the most points after 3-5 rounds will win!

—description from the designer

Name: Munchkin Starfinder: Hero Pack
Description:
Calling all Citizens of the Pact!

Add 15 cards that will transform you into a Starfinder Hero! Become a reptilian master of technological magic, or use your experience in the Swarm as you travel the ends of space to negotiate peace with alien planets!

This is an expansion for Munchkin Starfinder, it is not a stand-alone game.

Based on the Starfinder Roleplaying Game from Paizo Inc.

—description from the publisher

Name: Munchkin Starfinder: The Swarm
Description:
Add 15 more cards to Munchkin Starfinder to make the terrifying Swarm even more vicious . . . and silly! Make sure to carry your Swarm Repellent to avoid the Head Louse!

This is an expansion for Munchkin Starfinder. It is not a stand-alone game.

Based on the Starfinder Roleplaying Game from Paizo Inc.

—description from the publisher

Name: Philosopher: Game to Evolve Humanity
Description:
Philosopher is a card game in which you discuss subjects with friends & family that may not come up in small talk.  Some subjects are serious, some controversial, some esoteric, some funny, etc. 
The primary deck includes 50 Topic cards and 150 viewpoint cards.  
This is a deep conversational game, a profound adventure for the evolution of humanity. Go beyond the surface to know yourself, others & life better.

Games shift as players evolve and grow their life philosophies. The dynamic of the group will mold the trajectory of the game.  Rotate from playing the PHILOSOPHER (the person’s whose turn it is) and the DEVOTEES (other players).

Examples of Topics are Angels, Magic, Ghosts, Atlantis, Dreams.

—description from the designer

Name: Gloomhaven: Jaws of the Lion – Removable Sticker Set and Map
Description: Reset, replay, or resell your copy of Gloomhaven: Jaws of the Lion with this set of high quality removable vinyl stickers and city map board from Cephalofair. Featuring non-transferring adhesive, these stickers can be removed without damaging or tearing components.

Name: Monopoly: UNSW Edition
Description: Challenge your friends to a very special version of your favourite board game! The official UNSW Business School Monopoly features prominent campus locations for some UNSW-themed fun. Let the games begin!

Name: Lights! Camera! Actors!
Description:
Each card has 5 actors who have all appeared in the same movie.  Guess the movie after the first actor is called, you get 5 points. After two actors, you get 4 points. Points diminish until it gets down to the last actor.  Guess the movie after all 5 actors are named, you get 1 point.

To start the game, assign a person to keep score. Randomly pick one person to start the game. They pick the first card and read the first actor's name. They slowly read down the list of actors until either someone guesses the correct movie-- for which they are given the associated amount of points or they get to the end of the actor list without an answer. Either way, the card is put in the opposite end of the box and play moves on clockwise to the next person. Game ends when someone hits a pre-determined score milestone.

—description from the designer

Name: Star Fleet Battles: Captain's Log #33
Description:
I have nightmares of the Juggernaut, and I have never seen one.

Released in June 2006, this Captain’s Log issue supports Star Fleet Battles, Federation Commander, and Federation & Empire. “Snap Count,” by Stephen V. Cole, has the appearance of Juggernaut Beta in Federation territory. Can Star Fleet, combined with the Federation Police and National Guard, defend Arcturus?  “The Silence of the Dead,”  by Randy O. Green, follows a Romulan ship that finds a derelict alien vessel in Tholian territory.

In addition to the story, History includes information on Tholian patrol corvettes and destroyers, with a class history of the latter, along with details on the Klingon Empire Security Service and the G1 gunboat.

As is usual, Communications informs readers about the company’s activities. Captain’s Log #32 and Federation Commander: Klingon Attack have after-action reports. The company laid out its plans for new print releases and metal miniatures for the coming year, including new materials for Federation Commander. There are questions and answers about submissions to ADB. The Input Guide has information about the style sheet that ADB follows. Proposals for Star Fleet Battles are presented. Admiral Growler answers SFB questions. More “Why” questions get answered. There is a page of filk songs.

Federation Commander has prototype rules for the Lyrans’ expanding spheres. There is a page of tactics papers. The three following scenarios appear:

     The First Battle of Juggernaut Beta (Juggernaut Beta against anyone who wants to fight it),
     Starhunt, the Stolen Freighters (Orion pirates and police), and 
     the Battle of Juggernaut Alpha (Juggernaut Alpha faces the “allies”) provide challenges for Federation Commander players.


This issue includes six scenarios for Star Fleet Battles. * SL246, Stand at Arcturus, is based on the story “Snap Count.” 

     SL247, Tentative Response, is set in the Magellanic Galaxy and pits Maghadim against the Baduvai.  
     SL248, Different Romulans, set during the Early Years, involves an encounter between the Vulcans and Gorns. 
     SL249, And None Shall Pass, is set in the Omega Octant and is a two-way battle between the Loriyill and Drex. A three-way version allows a third player to fly the Chlorophon ship. 
     SL250, A Dark and Stormy Day, has the Hydrans facing the Vudar.  
     SL251, Who Ordered the PFs?, a battle station’s PFs are absent, but a tug is on the way with replacements. Will the tug get the gunboats to the battle station in time without being destroyed itself?


Database articles include battlegroups designed with 1,00 points and the required use of a tug or light tactical transport if the empire didn’t have a tug. There is an article on the sun snake. SFB campaigns get a new rule for casual cargo storage. The Fast Patrol ship campaign is updated. There is a guide for Tholians to convert captured foreign ships to fit into Tholian fleets and vice versa.

The Tactics section has “Fog of War 4” by Jim Hart. The primer focuses on the Magellanic empires, exploring this new region’s standard tactics and counter-tactics. There are two pages of term papers.

The Venues section covers Star Fleet Command, SFB On-Line, playing by email, Galactic Conquest, Star Fleet Warlord, Prime Directive (with a look at Tholian biology), and Star Fleet Battle Force.

Federation & Empire has a status update along with rules and rulings, Q&A, and proposals. There are two pages of tactical notes. There is a new scenario, (674) The Long Distance War.

New ships are added for Star Fleet Battles. Everyone gets the civilian planetary operations base. The Federation gets the following destroyer variations: emergency management ship, Middle Years destroyer, deckhouse destroyer, deckhouse light carrier, deckhouse destroyer transport, heavy destroyer, heavy destroyer carrier, heavy destroyer transport, heavy destroyer minesweeper, and heavy commando transport.  
The Tholians get the scout destroyer and “White Widow” destroyer carrier, both destroyer variants. They also get SSDs for the following captured ships: Federation police cutter, Romulan police ship, Orion Light Raider, and Klingon G2 gunboat. Juggernaut Beta from the cover story gets its SSD. Federation Commander gets new ship cards for the Lyran Jaguar war cruiser, Hydran Mongol medium cruiser, WYN war cruiser, and ISC light cruiser. These four ships are in fleet scale.

—description from the publisher

Name: Marvel: Crisis Protocol – Cable & Domino
Description:
The son of the X-Men leader Cyclops, Cable was sent to the future to save his life when he was infected by the deadly techno-organic virus. Raised by Clan Askani, Cable was able to use his own incredible mutant powers to keep the virus in check, though the constant strain limits him from reaching his true potential. Granted incredible telepathic and telekinetic powers from his mutation, Cable is also equipped with advanced weaponry and technology from the 38th century. Having traveled back in time, Cable now seeks to change the apocalyptic future from which he grew up and ensure a better world for all.

Neena Thurman, a.k.a. Domino, was the product of an illicit government program whose goal was to create the ultimate mutant weapon. Unwilling to be a pawn of anyone, Domino escaped with the help of her powers and set out to find her own path in the world. With her ability to manipulate probability fields — ensuring things always go her way — and her extensive training in armed and unarmed combat, Domino became one of the most dangerous mercenaries in the world. Not long after, Domino found a new home and purpose as a hero as a mainstay member of X-Force.

Marvel: Crisis Protocol – Cable & Domino consists of 2 miniatures, 2 Bases, 1 Crisis Card, 1 Affiliation Card, 2 Character Stat Cards, 4 Team Tactic Cards, and 11 Tokens.

Name: Marvel: Crisis Protocol – Luke Cage & Iron Fist
Description:
Jailed for a crime he didn't commit, Harlem-born Carl Lucas agreed to undergo an experimental treatment designed to replicate the effects of the Super-Soldier serum that produced Captain America. As a result of the treatment, Carl's skin became unbreakable, and his strength was amplified to superhuman levels. Now bullet proof and able to punch through four-inch-thick steel, Carl took on the name Luke Cage and became a hero dedicated to keeping his streets safe alongside his partner and friend Iron Fist.

Born into privilege, Danny Rand's life was forever changed when his parents were killed by a family friend. Fueled by a desire for revenge, Danny traveled to the mystical city of K'un-Lun. There he trained under Lei Kung the Thunderer, who turned him into a living weapon. As a final test, Danny challenged the dragon Shou-Lao and defeated him. Plunging his fist into the dragon's molten heart, Danny became the bearer of the Iron Fist. After avenging his parents, Danny turned his life to serving others, becoming inseparable friends with Luke Cage as a Defender, Avenger, and a Hero for Hire.

Marvel: Crisis Protocol – Luke Cage & Iron Fist consists of 2 miniatures, 2 Bases, 2 Character Stat Cards, 3 Team Tactic Cards, and 11 Tokens.

Name: Werewolf: The Apocalypse – RETALIATION
Description:
A new violent, mature and Visceral roleplaying board gameboard game set in the World of Darkness.

Intended for solo play as well as up to four players, Werewolf: The Apocalypse — RETALIATION takes place in Yosemite Valley, following a deadly battle that left your pack all but decimated. With only a full lunar cycle to recover, rebuild your Caern, and prepare for your final revenge against Wyrm entities, your choices will weigh heavily upon the fate of your characters.

The game includes immersive branching scenarios, intense combats, mesmerizing investigations, beautiful minis, and a profound roleplaying experience.

—description from the designer

Name: A Song of Ice & Fire: Tabletop Miniatures Game – Lannister Red Cloaks
Description:
When it comes to House Lannister, they spare no expense on those that take up arms for the House. The Red Cloaks are the Lannister's elite guards that patrol the streets in both King's Landing and Casterly Rock. Their resplendent red cloaks, their signature feature, is colored not just because it's a House color, but as a show of intimidation to the populace. "Stay in line, or the Red Cloaks will come after you".

The unit box A Song of Ice & Fire: Tabletop Miniatures Game – Lannister Red Cloaks gives House Lannister players a new medium infantry unit for their force. The Red Cloaks are armored in half-plate, the best that money can buy for mass production. This gives them a modicum of defense, able to turn away blows from all but the strongest enemy soldiers. Being paid well also serves them on the battlefield, as they know they don’t want to lose that next paycheck.
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Game: A Song of Ice & Fire – Tabletop Miniatures Game

Name: A Song of Ice & Fire: Tabletop Miniatures Game – Targaryen Dothraki Outriders
Description:
The Dothraki Outriders are generally used as scouting forces, using their superior riding skills to spy on the enemy and ascertain the best way for the main army to attack. But once the battle has started, a whole new facet of the unit becomes apparent: they're also master archers. Archers are generally slower units in an army. Obviously, that's not the case when your archer is also a master rider.

The A Song of Ice & Fire: Tabletop Miniatures Game – Targaryen Dothraki Outriders unit box gives House Targaryen players a swift ranged force for their army. These lightly armored mounted troops make full use of their horses both before and after raining arrows down on their opponents. With their great speed, the Dothraki Outriders can reach out and deal damage to enemies normally considered safe along the back lines of an army. Enemy commanders will have a difficult time pinning down these highly mobile troops.
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Game: A Song of Ice & Fire – Tabletop Miniatures Game

Name: A Song of Ice & Fire: Tabletop Miniatures Game – Targaryen Dothraki Hrakkers
Description:
Taming one of the great white lions of the Dothraki Sea is a feat accomplished by only the mightiest khals. The Hrakkars are powerful beasts that match even the famed Stark Direwolves in terms of conferred status, and in war is just as fearsome a sight on the field. Fast, deadly, and above all stealthy, troops facing the Dothraki should beware of sudden attacks from unsuspected quarters by lurking Hrakkars.

The A Song of Ice & Fire: Tabletop Miniatures Game – Targaryen Dothraki Hrakkers unit box gives you new options fielding options for your forces.
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Game: A Song of Ice & Fire – Tabletop Miniatures Game

Name: KFC's Actiespel
Description:
This game is closely related to KFC's Assano.
Just like KFC's Assano, this Bigger version is a promotional game.

The box contains the same cards as KFC's Assano, but expands them with the following:

This version has a few extra cards compared to the Multi-Lingual version, namely:

     7 Cards with number 6-9, plus 1 "draw-1" card, in the color yellow.
     7 Cards with number 6-9, plus 1 "draw-1" card, in the color blue.
     7 Cards with number 6-9, plus 1 "draw-1" card, in the color green.
     7 Cards with number 6-9, plus 1 "draw-1" card, in the color red.


As this is a Dutch only version, the rules are only in Dutch, but on two cards instead of one.

Gameplay and rules are basically the same KFC's Assano.

—user summary

Name: Infrastructure
Description:
You've been charged with tailored development of your city, improve the infrastructure while aiming to be the most successful administrator. Players take turns placing tiles on a 5x5 board after which points are scored according to each players target scoring pad.
Player with most victory points emerges as the winning administrator.

—description from the designer

Name: G'schwind
Description:
G’schwind is a funny song board game for the young and old, for lovers of pop music, folk music and children's songs.

400 word cards
1 hourglass
1 board
4 gramophone figures

Rules
The player draws one or more word cards within the given time and he is allowed to move one or more fields with the gramophone figure for each song performed. However, only if the word from the word card appears in the performed song and the melody is recognizable. The word on the drawn word card may also be part of a word family in the lyrics. For example "survive" and "survivor"
A total of 4 significant icons are drawn on the board game as special hurdles or obstacles: Whistling, Humming, Double Time and "I Sing For You".

—description from the designer

Name: Nuclear Escalation: New Cards
Description: Unofficial expansion consisting of six new cards for Nuclear Escalation that appeared in Space Gamer magazine (Issue 74 - May 1985)

Name: ¡Caiaaate!
Description:
Caiaaate is a quick card game in which players try to be the first to get rid of their face-down stack of cards. 
Players take turn playing a card from their stack openly on a pile, making the sound that the card tells them. However, if the sound would be the same as the sound just made by the previous player, they have to invent a different sound. When a player plays a "shh" card, everybody must immediately be silent and put one hand down on the table.
